name: places/ChIJt4KU2O5ZwokR50W_sxtBWyM
formattedAddress: 237 East 86th St, New York, NY 10028, USA
adrFormatAddress: 237 East 86th St, New York, NY 10028, USA

originalText.text: I purchased a 3-class pass to see if this was something I would like. I'm pretty used to boot camp-style classes. And by far Barry’s was such a great experience. I got an awesome workout in each class and the staff seemed really engaged. However the only pain point is the pricing per class, it's expensive if you're taking classes a few times a week. But if it's in your budget it's a great time. I will be returning.

originalText.text: I’ve been to all other Barry’s in the city but this one have major issue when it comes to the fuel bar, for the fourth Sunday my shake is BLAND, no flavors whatsoever just iced water with color! It’s not one person but each Sunday another barista girl and another tasteless drink! They all super nice but please maybe more training? Or mix staff up with other locations because I’m done traveling there.

text.text: I’ve been to all other Barry’s in the city but this one have major issue when it comes to the fuel bar, for the fourth Sunday my shake is BLAND, no flavors whatsoever just iced water with color! It’s not one person but each Sunday another barista girl and another tasteless drink! They all super nice but please maybe more training? Or mix staff up with other locations because I’m done traveling there.

originalText.text:
It's a pretty good bootcamp. Some things they could improve considering steep price of $40 for 50 min:
1.  Run the air conditioning better. People shouldn't start sweating just due to the temperature in the room. Presumably fitness experts like Barry's know people exercise better in cooler temp. I am a little bit afraid to think how hot it will get in summer.
2. If the class is not full - don't combine everyone into treadmills to start the class. I very much like to start with weights and pick a spot to avoid having a "buddy". Nothing worse than sharing a spot with a big guy dripping with sweat. It's already very tight space, combining everyone on treads makes coach' life easier but   it's so uncomfortable trying to avoid not being hit into face by your neighbor's dumbbell or foot.
3.  Emphasize to big guys that they must wipe their sweat after using the weight station or the treadmill as it's a shared spot.
4. Some instructors are so hard to understand, especially when they pepper the breaks between instructions with some personal nonsense like their favorite bands. It takes a lot of effort to stay on top of commands.
5. Some instructors come in the middle of the room to demonstrate and those are the best!

All in all it's a great  bootcamp and I already recruited few friends. Barry on!

originalText.text:
So happy Barry’s opened their location on E 86th!! I work out all over the city and Barry’s have been one of my favorite studios to go to (and to check out when I visit new cities). It’s always a consistently hard workout, no matter which city or location, and the class is always a good time! the difference is just the energy / vibes of each instructor.
I love this location and the staff here.

originalText.text: I have been to three different locations of Barry’s. This location is the worst! The coach was super fun and nice. The problem is the front desk, she was super rude to me and my friends. When we first walked in, she gave us an unwelcoming feeling, then took our name. When she sees “Americans” walked in, her face was different. I can somehow sense she is a racist and not welcoming Asian people here! So no, thanks! I won't come back to this location ever!
